Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A bride-to-be and her entourage arrive early, visibly anxious about the tight wedding schedule.
Story: I was in the back room, just about to grab my scissors, when my phone buzzed. It was a message from Jamie: “Can you talk? I really need you.” I knew today was the day Jamie’s boss would announce the new team lead, and Jamie had been agonizing over whether to speak up about a project mistake. My heart twisted—I wanted to be there, to listen, to reassure. But as I stepped out, I saw the bride and her friends already waiting, their faces tense, glancing at their watches. I could hear their nervous laughter, the way they clung to each other, desperate for everything to go perfectly. My manager shot me a look: “They’re early, but let’s get started.” I felt pulled in two directions—my partner needed me, but so did these clients, expecting warmth and calm. My hands trembled as I reached for my phone, torn between the comfort Jamie needed and the welcoming smile my clients expected.
